stream_context.summary: Kaze works on Course 1 of Return to Yoshi’s Island, replacing the first-overworld ‘playground’ with interactive tutorial bunnies. He programs their behaviour, creates temporary billboard textures that show control prompts, and prototypes a rotating sparkle ring that awards a coin when the required move is performed. Visual polish (shading, wood textures, Mario lighting) and low-level optimisations (trig functions, cache blocks) are also discussed while testing a YouTube stream as an alternative to Twitch.

development_findings.summary: Course 1 received new wood for the windmill, added mushroom shadows, and overall darker/softer shading tweaks.
Three ‘tutorial bunnies’ will be added to Course 1, each teaching one move: mid-air dive, wall-kick, and spin-jump.
development_findings.quote: Basically, we're going to add these tutorial bunnies to Course 1 that are going to teach you the movements.

development_findings.summary: Design revision: Coin is only granted after the player performs the move through a particle ring triggered by talking to the bunny, preventing accidental skips.
development_findings.quote: We don't want players to miss the move… so let's make rings for players to go through with the specified move to get the coin.

development_findings.summary: Tutorial UI will use billboarded 64×64 textures above each bunny showing ‘Z→A’, ‘A→A’, ‘Z→B’, etc.; textures must stay within 16-colour indexed limits of N64.
Kaze prototyped rotating double sparkle rings spawned via a custom particle routine; uses two clockwise/counter-clockwise rings for readability and taught chat how he optimises the draw code.
Camera is never forced to rotate during gameplay; any cut-scene motion must keep player control predictable—hence manual camera parameters were hard-coded for the bunny demo.
development_findings.quote: If you make the camera rotate without the player being able to predict it, you're always going to have the player hold a direction they don't intend.

development_findings.summary: Engine status: ~70 % complete; most core upgrades done; project in development ~3 years; intends to release source once game ships.
Recent low-level work: faster sine/cosine functions and grouping render routines into 0x400-byte I-cache blocks; has d-cache optimisations as well.
Original SM64 object-shadow system is labelled ‘terrible’; RTYI bakes static shadows and allows per-level lighting tweaks (direction, colour).
Considering adding multiplayer; would be unlocked from the start if implemented.
Plans to port his Banjo-Kazooie hack into the RTYI engine as a bonus.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is testing YouTube because Twitch’s forced ads frustrate him; platform switch undecided.
context_findings.quote: Twitch forces you to run an ad every 30 minutes… let's test out YouTube.

context_findings.summary: Week off work (Easter) lets him stream on a Thursday; he normally maintains a rigid Twitch schedule.
He lives in Canada, keeps workout equipment beside his desk, and jokes about constant exercising during coding.
Views long projects as ‘pure torture’ after initial fun; estimates <4 % of large ROM-hack projects finish; advises newcomers to start small.
context_findings.quote: That's why I always tell people to start with a small project… otherwise they are just going to not get anything done at all.

context_findings.summary: Legal awareness: past tutorials and a climate-change ROM hack were DMCA’d by Nintendo; RTYI will be open-sourced post-release.

biobak.summary: Provided feedback on shading hardness around grass edges and will redo billboard textures into a single material to save memory.
biobak.quote: Biobak is right about the tutorial though… You get to make the billboards.

biobak.summary: Performed ‘a lot of revamping’ of Course 1 art to make it prettier; earlier wood and overall visuals credited to him.

zeina.summary: Supplied a work-in-progress animation clip (possibly for a flying enemy or object); Kaze notes pivot issues and bounce quality.
zeina.quote: It looks a little like he's not rotating around his actual middle… but I like the bounce.

key_stories.title: Building the Tutorial Bunny System
key_stories.summary: Kaze wants beginners to learn advanced moves without text-heavy pop-ups. He codes rabbits that demonstrate the move, display a control prompt, spawn a sparkling ring, and award a coin only if the move is executed correctly.
key_stories.challenge: Teach dive, wall-kick, and spin-jump in a way novices cannot miss yet veterans can ignore.
key_stories.process: Iterated with chat on prompt clarity, rewrote particle code for a readable ring, moved bunny positions, forced cut-scene camera, and refined collision heights.
key_stories.outcome: Working prototype in Course 1; art and animations to be finalised by Biobak and Kaze on Saturday.
key_stories.key_quote: We don't want players to miss the move, so let's make rings for players to go through with the specified move to get the coin.

key_stories.title: Testing a Platform Migration
key_stories.summary: Twitch’s invasive ads push Kaze to try streaming on YouTube during his Easter break. He gauges viewer turnout, chat readability, and monetisation options (donations, mod tools).
key_stories.challenge: Maintain audience engagement without Twitch’s existing follower base while avoiding platform bans on dual-streaming.
key_stories.process: Announces unplanned Thursday YouTube stream, mods regulars, disables non-skippable ads, discusses policy differences.
key_stories.outcome: Positive viewership and donations but decision remains open; acknowledges biases when asking each platform’s audience.
key_stories.key_quote: If you only ask YouTube viewers whether they want you to stay on YouTube… they're all going to say stay on YouTube.

key_stories.title: Clarifying Control-Prompt Graphics
key_stories.summary: First billboard texture (‘Z→A’) was misconstrued by chat; Kaze and Biobak debate readability and 16-colour constraints.
key_stories.challenge: Create N64-legal 64×64 textures that unambiguously convey sequential button presses.
key_stories.process: Kaze experiments in Photoshop/GIMP, fights indexing artefacts, enlarges ‘Z’, adds outlines; Biobak volunteers to rebuild as a single material.
key_stories.outcome: Temporary placeholders implemented; final assets delegated to Biobak.
key_stories.key_quote: No way someone misunderstood this to mean press A first—there’s an actual arrow.
